Fig. 1 Schematic diagram of photocatalytic apparatus of glycerol conversion. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 HRTEM images of C-doped TiO2 synthesized by sol-microwave method with different cellulose loadings and microwave treating times. Inset in each HRTEM image is the corresponding SEM image. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 X-ray diffraction patterns of C-doped TiO2 synthesized by sol-microwave method with different cellulose loadings and microwave treating times. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 FTIR spectra of cellulose, as-syn 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) and calcined C-doped TiO2 photocatalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XPS spectra of 10 %Cel-TiO2 (0-MW), 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) and TiO2 (4-MW); (a) survey spectra, (b) high-resolution XPS spectra of Ti2p, (c) high-resolution XPS spectra of O1s and (d) high-resolution XPS spectra of C1s. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) UV–vis DR spectra of C-doped TiO2 synthesized by sol-microwave method with different cellulose loadings and microwave treating times and (b) the plot of (αhν)1/2 versus photon energy (eV). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Photocatalytic conversions of glycerol with C-doped TiO2 photocatalysts synthesized by sol-microwave method under different microwave treating times. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Yields of products obtained from photocatalytic conversions of glycerol with C-doped TiO2 synthesized by sol-microwave with different microwave treating times (0, 4 and 20 min). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Photocatalytic conversions of glycerol with C-doped TiO2 photocatalysts synthesized by sol-microwave method with different cellulose loadings. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 A systematic mechanism of C-doped TiO2 under visible light. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Yields of products obtained from photocatalytic conversions of glycerol with C-doped TiO2 synthesized by sol-microwave with different cellulose loadings during synthesis. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 Proposed pathway model of photocatalytic conversion of glycerol to GAL, DHA, FA and AA over C-doped TiO2 photocatalysts in water under visible-light irradiation. Fig. 12 Fig. 13 Plot of glycerol conversion vs carbon content of 10 % Cel-TiO2 synthesized with different sol-microwave treating times. Synthesis of C-doped TiO2 by sol-microwave method for photocatalytic conversion of glycerol to value-added chemicals under visible light Jiraporn Payormhorm a b Raphael Idem b * a The Joint Graduate School for Energy and Environment (JGSEE), King Mongkut's University of Technology Thonburi, Prachauthit Road, Bangmod, Bangkok 10140, Thailand The Joint Graduate School for Energy and Environment (JGSEE) King Mongkut's University of Technology Thonburi Prachauthit Road, Bangmod Bangkok 10140 Thailand The Joint Graduate School for Energy and Environment (JGSEE), King Mongkut's University of Technology Thonburi, Prachauthit Road, Bangmod, Bangkok 10140, Thailand b Clean Energy Technologies Research Institute (CETRI), Faculty of Engineering and Applied Science, University of Regina, Regina, Saskatchewan S4S 0A2, Canada Clean Energy Technologies Research Institute (CETRI) Faculty of Engineering and Applied Science University of Regina Regina Saskatchewan S4S 0A2 Canada Clean Energy Technologies Research Institute (CETRI), Faculty of Engineering and Applied Science, University of Regina, Regina, Saskatchewan S4S 0A2, Canada ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract C-doped TiO2 photocatalyst synthesized using a one-step sol-microwave method with microcrystalline cellulose as the carbon source to achieve TiO2 of desirable visible light absorption, cluster size, surface area and band gap was applied in the photocatalytic oxidation of glycerol under visible light to produce value-added chemicals, for the first time. An increase in microwave irradiation time from 0 to 20 min reduced the anatase crystal size but increased the surface area, pore volume and pore radius. Carbon coupled with microwave treatment produced Ti3+ and oxygen vacancies in the TiO2 lattice of the C-doped TiO2 which yielded improved performance of the photocatalysts. For example, a cellulose loading at 10 % (i.e. 10 % Cel-TiO2(4-MW)) provided the highest photo-conversion of glycerol (67.5 %) and highest yields of glyceraldehyde (10.0 %), dihydroxyacetone (7.4 %), formic acid (49.0 %) and acetic acid (1.8 %). On the other hand, excess residual carbon on TiO2 surface (e.g. 20 % Cel-TiO2(0-MW)) retarded the activity of the photocatalyst. Keywords Photocatalysis Glycerol conversion Carbon-doped TiO2 Sol-microwave Value-added compound 1 Introduction Photocatalysis is an enabler of one of the cleanest chemical/catalytic processes because it allows the process to operate efficiently under light and mild operating conditions as well as with less release of pollutants. Also, the solar energy employed in the process is the largest, cheapest and main alternative energy resource which can be converted to chemical energy with photocatalysts. In addition, solar energy also reduces the use of fossil fuels which can help to minimize environmental problems [1,2]. It is well known that biorefinery processes, which can be considered as a sustainable process for energy and bio-chemicals production, emphasizes the use of biomass and agricultural by-products as feedstock and approach to develop products and systems [2]. Glycerol is the main by-product produced in biodiesel production by transesterification of triglycerides (fat and oils) with alcohol. The use of glycerol has generated a lot of interest in recent times as a way of utilizing a waste product to produce value-added products. It is of interest to utilize glycerol as a platform chemical in the biorefinery process for production of high-value added chemicals because glycerol is a highly functionalized and versatile organic compound [3,4]. Oxidation, which is a common reaction for conversion of glycerol, can produce many types of value-added chemicals such as dihydroxyacetone, glyceraldehyde, glyceric acid, glycolic acid, tartronic acid and oxalic acid, etc. [4,5]. The combination of photocatalysis and biorefinery approaches can create a promising technology for production of clean bio-energy and bio-chemicals due to the high potential of photocatalytic oxidation. According to the literature [6], a heterogeneous photocatalyst comprises of a solid semiconductor such as TiO2, ZnO, WO3, CdS, CdSe, Fe2O3, ZnS, Ge3N4, etc. Metal and metal free solid photocatalysts such as CdS quantum dots, Ni/CdS and carbon nitride (g-C3N4) have also been used in the literature [7–9] in the valorization of biomass and its derivatives to produce aromatic monomers, furfural, furoic acid, H2, etc. The photocatalytic conversion of glycerol was studied by photo-oxidation on ZnO and silica-entrapped Bi2WO6 to produce mainly glyceraldehyde (GA) and dihydroxyacetone (DHA). Zhang and co-workers [10] used silica-entrapped Bi2WO6 as the photocatalyst in the photocatalytic selective oxidation of glycerol in water under visible light (>420 nm). The silica-entrapped Bi2WO6 provided the highest glycerol conversion of 58 % in 10 h with selectivity of DHA and GA of 91 % and 6 %, respectively [10]. Hermes et al. [11] studied the parameters for glycerol conversion with ZnO under UV light and observed that the optimum conditions were a base solution (pH 11) at a temperature of 50 °C for which the glycerol conversion was 65 % in 1 h. According to the literature [12,13], titanium dioxide (TiO2) stands out as an excellent solid photocatalyst due to its high efficiency under UV light, excellent chemical stability, nontoxicity, low cost, and photo-corrosion resistance. That is why it is widely used in many applications such as fuel production, organic pollutant degradation, CO2 photoreduction, recharge ability in batteries, etc. [2,14–16]. However, the photocatalytic performance of TiO2 is restricted by its wide energy gap, high rate of electron-hole recombination, and small surface area [17]. The wide band gap of TiO2 (∼3.2 eV) causes limitation in the utilization of solar light because it responds only in the UV radiation, which is 3–5 % of solar light, leaving 45 % of visible light unused [18–20]. The light absorption region of TiO2 can be extended into the visible light region by metal doping, non-metal doping and dye sensitizing techniques [19,21]. Among these techniques, non-metal doping techniques provide a greater efficiency in the light absorption of TiO2 in the visible-light region. Also, carbon doped TiO2 has a higher photo-corrosion resistance, thermal stability and durability as compared with metal doped- and dye sensitized-TiO2 [21]. Carbon doping can also prevent the release of toxic materials from metal leaching [22]. The literature [21,23] also shows that carbon-doped TiO2 can also enhance photocatalytic efficiency by improving charge transfer efficiency, suppression of charge recombination and providing large electron-storage capacity. Previously, many researchers have reported on the fabrication of C-doped TiO2 by the traditional sol-gel, hydrothermal and impregnation methods by using hydrocarbon compounds (such as glucose, sucrose, cellulose fiber and lignin) in biomass as carbon precursor [24–28]. The sol-microwave method is an alternative fabrication method which applies microwave irradiation during the sol-gel process. It provides a rapid homogeneous heat transfer and short reaction time in the synthesis of nanomaterials [28–30], which enhances uniform nucleation of nanoparticles and reduces the size and aggregation of the TiO2 particles. This is because the rotation, friction and collisions of titanium precursor and solvent molecules occur during TiO2 particle formation under the electric field of microwave irradiation. According to our earlier work [31], that was the reason that TiO2 synthesized under microwave power gave a higher photocatalytic performance as compared with TiO2 synthesized without microwave irradiation [31]. Previous studies have applied microwave irradiation in the synthesis of TiO2 photocatalysts for various applications. For example, Zhao et al. [30] enhanced the hydrogen production performance with Fe-doped TiO2 synthesized through microwave-hydrothermal synthesis. Also, Yu et al. [32] synthesized CuO/TiO2 nano-rods by a facile two-step microwave-assisted-solvothermal method and then used the obtained catalysts in photocatalytic hydrogen evolution by photocatalytic water splitting. In addition, various TiO2 catalysts synthesized with the microwave-assisted method have been tested for their photocatalytic activity in the degradation of dye and pollutants [28,33–35]. However, although various TiO2 photocatalysts have been synthesized by the microwave-assisted method, they have not been applied to date for photocatalytic conversion of glycerol, to the best of our knowledge. Recently, Lui et al. [28] have reported the synthesis of carbon doped TiO2 photocatalysts by a microwave-hydrothermal method (>140 °C for 20 min) but they used the extracted lignin obtained from biomass as the carbon source. Nevertheless, their synthesized carbon doped TiO2 indicated good photocatalytic activity for methylene blue degradation under ultraviolet and visible light. In this work, carbon doped TiO2 photocatalysts were firstly fabricated by a one-step sol-microwave method using microcrystalline cellulose as the carbon source. The effect of cellulose loading and treating time under microwave irradiation on extending the visible light response, improving morphologies and activity of TiO2 were examined. The photocatalytic activity of carbon doped TiO2 photocatalysts was tested, for the first time, in the photocatalytic conversion of glycerol. In addition, the yield and variety of value-added chemicals obtained from the conversion of glycerol were determined. Furthermore, the mechanism of formation of the various value-added products have also been proposed. 2 Materials and method 2.1 Photocatalyst preparation In this study, all TiO2 samples were prepared by the sol-gel method. Equal moles of titanium (IV) butoxide (Ti(OC4H9)4) (97.0 %, Sigma-Aldrich, 17.1446 g) and acetylacetone (>99 %, Sigma-Aldrich) were mixed at room temperature to decelerate hydrolysis and condensation reactions. Different loadings of carbon on TiO2 were achieved by suspending microcrystalline cellulose powder (90 μm, ACROS) in the solution of titanium(IV) butoxide mixed with acetylacetone (5 %, 10 % and 20 %wt). Nanopure water (120 mL) was added dropwise to the suspension of cellulose under vigorous stirring, followed by isopropyl alcohol (≥99.5 %, Honeywell, 80 mL). The resulting mixture was kept at room temperature for 1 h, and then transferred into a specific container for microwave irradiation. A domestic microwave oven (Panasonic, 2.45 GHz, 970 W) was employed to rapidly heat the mixture for 4 and 20 min. A precipitate of cellulose-TiO2 composite was obtained for each synthesis which was then dried overnight in an oven at 80 °C. All samples were pulverized to powder, followed by calcination at 500 °C for 2 h. A calcined C-doped TiO2 sample was labeled as A%Cel-TiO2(B-MW), where A, and B-MW refer to the percentage of cellulose and microwave treating time, respectively. 2.2 Photocatalyst characterization The phase composition and crystal structure of TiO2 particles were characterized by X-ray diffraction (Bruker, D8 Discover) with Cu-Kα radiation (λ =0.154 nm at 40 kV, 40 mA) at the rate of 0.05° s−1 and scanning angle from 15° to 80°. The average crystal size was estimated according to the Scherrer Eq. (1): (1) D = K λ β c o s θ where D is the crystallite size, K is a coefficient (0.94), λ is the wavelength of the X-ray radiation, β is derived from full-width at half-maximum intensity of peak, and θ is the angle of diffraction. The particle size and morphology of TiO2 particles was monitored using the scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM). Surface area, pore volume and pore size distribution of the TiO2 samples were determined using N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77.0 K (Belsorp Mini II, Japan) using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The elemental composition in the TiO2 samples was examined by an elemental analyzer (JS-science, JM10) at the combustion temperature of 850 °C under helium. The chemical states and surface composition of TiO2 were investigated using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha) equipped with an Al Kα radiation source. The survey scans of surface compositions were derived with an energy step size of 1.00 eV and a pass energy of 200.0 eV. The high-resolution spectra of C1s, O1s, and Ti2p were obtained with an energy step size of 0.1 eV and a pass energy of 50.0 eV. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra of samples were recorded with a spectrophotometer (Agilent Technologies, carry 5000) in the region of 200−800 nm. Band gap energies (Eg ) of carbon doped TiO2 samples were calculated according to the intersection of the extrapolated linear portion in the plot of (αhv)1/2 versus the photon energy (hν = 1240/wavelength) by Eq. (2): (2) α h v 1 / 2 = h v - E g where α is absorption coefficient which is linearly proportional to the absorbance of sample [36]. 2.3 Photocatalytic conversion of glycerol In the glycerol conversion experiment, 200 mL of an aqueous glycerol solution (5 g/L) was transferred into a borosilicate reactor. Then, TiO2 photocatalyst powder (0.3 g) was loaded into glycerol solution. The TiO2 suspension was continuously stirred in darkness for 30 min to obtain complete adsorption of glycerol on TiO2 surface. The schematic diagram of the photocatalytic experimental apparatus is shown in Fig. 1 . The suspension was irradiated from outside of the reactor with a 400 W metal halide lamp (λ > 400 nm) as the solar light source. The light intensity at the surface of the reactor was 21.3 × 104 lux. A volume of 30 % H2O2 was added into the glycerol solution prior to the start of the photoreaction. The photocatalytic reaction itself was conducted under continuous air flow (200 mL/min) through the reactor. A condenser was set at the top of the reactor to avoid loss of solution by evaporation. During the irradiation period, 3 mL samples were withdrawn from the photoreactor at specified time intervals and then filtered through 0.22-mm nylon filter to separate the photocatalyst from the solution. Glycerol conversion and product yield were measured using a high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, Agilent 1100) machine equipped with a refractive index detector (RID, Agilent 1100) and a diode-array detector (DAD, Agilent 1100). The separation of generated products was performed via a Hi-Plex H column (300 × 7.7 mm, 8 μm) at 60 °C using 5 mM sulfuric acid as the mobile phase at a constant flow rate of 0.6 mL/min. 2.4 Calculations The conversion of glycerol and yield of products were calculated according to Eq. (3) and (4), respectively. (3) C o n v e r s i o n o f g l y c e r o l % = C g l y , o - C g l y , t C g l y , o × 100 (4) Y i e l d o f p r o d u c t % = C p r o d u c t , t C g l y , o × 100 where Cgly,o is the concentration of glycerol at t =0 h, Cgly,t is the concentration of glycerol at any specific time and Cproduct,t is the concentration of products obtained from glycerol conversion at any specific time. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Photocatalyst characterization 3.1.1 Morphology of C-doped TiO2 The transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images of C-doped TiO2 particles synthesized by sol-microwave method with different microwave treating times and cellulose loadings are shown in Fig. 2 . The corresponding scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images are also presented as inserts in each HRTEM image. The d-space of each C-doped TiO2 are also presented in the images of the figure. It is indicated in the figure that the lattice fringe of all C-doped TiO2 particles is 3.27–3.37 Å, related to the (1 0 1) facet of anatase. It needs to be mentioned that the presence of carbon in the photocatalyst was observed only in TiO2 (4-MW) and 5 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) because of the small agglomeration and denseness of particles. For the case of microwave treating time, it was found that 10 %Cel-TiO2 (0-MW) without microwave treatment possessed larger spherical clusters as compared with 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) and 10 %Cel-TiO2 (20-MW). Small clusters with irregular shapes were observed in C-doped TiO2 synthesized by microwave treatment. It was also observed through HRTEM images that 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) and 10 %Cel-TiO2 (20-MW) were composed of lower dense clusters of particle formation. Considering the effect of cellulose loading, it was observed that non-cellulose loading TiO2(4-MW) showed irregular spherical clusters with a rough surface due to nucleation and formation of TiO2 particles under the microwave electric field. However, TiO2 aggregation appeared in TiO2(4-MW) because of the interaction of inter-chain hydrogen bond of the polymeric Ti(IV) hydroxide obtained from hydrolysis and condensation during synthesis [37]. The aggregation of TiO2 particles decreased slightly by the addition of cellulose during synthesis because Ti(IV) hydroxide could now bind with the polar hydroxyl groups of cellulose by electrostatic interaction [25,38]. As a result, an increase in cellulose loading during synthesis under microwave treatment tended to reduce the aggregation of TiO2 particles. 3.1.2 Structure of C-doped TiO2 The X-ray diffraction patterns of C-doped TiO2 are shown in Fig. 3 . All the synthesized C-doped TiO2 revealed only the anatase phase which exhibit diffraction peaks at 25.2°, 37.9°, 48.3°, 53.8°, 55.3° and 62.7° (i.e. in diffraction lines). These positions of peaks represent the indices of (1 0 1), (1 0 3), (2 0 0), (1 0 5), (2 1 1) and (2 1 3) planes (JCPDS 21–1272), respectively [39]. XRD results revealed that without cellulose loading, TiO2 (4-MW) showed poor crystallinity of anatase, compared with cellulose loaded TiO2 photocatalysts. The crystallite size of anatase was calculated from the strongest diffraction peak (1 0 1) using the Scherrer Eq. (1). The results are shown in Table 1 . The results indicate that non-microwave treated 10 %Cel-TiO2 (0-MW) sample had a bigger size of anatase (6.5 nm) than the microwave treated C-doped TiO2 samples. These results show that an increase in microwave treating time reduced the anatase crystal size from 6.5 nm to 5.9 nm. According to the literature [31], this reduction occurs because of the rapid heating and longer duration of microwave irradiation which lead to a faster crystallization, thereby hindering the growth of anatase. On the other hand, it was observed in the current study that the increase in cellulose loading in C-TiO2 synthesis did not affect the crystallite size of anatase. 3.1.3 FTIR analysis The surface chemistry of the samples was monitored by FTIR spectroscopy. Fig. 4 shows the FTIR spectra of cellulose, 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) without calcination (as-syn 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW)) and calcined C-doped TiO2 photocatalysts (500 °C under N2 flow). The FTIR spectrum of cellulose displayed a broad peak at ≈ 3380 cm−1 that was attributed to the OH bond stretching of hydroxyl groups of cellulose. It also displayed a peak at ≈ 2900 cm−1 that was associated with the stretching vibration of C–H. The small peaks at ≈ 1440 cm−1 and 1370 were attributed to the presence of −CH2 and C–H bending in cellulose molecular structure, respectively. A strong peak at ≈ 1060 cm-1 is associated with the C–O stretching vibration. It is composed of small shoulder peaks at ≈ 1,160, 1030 and 1110 cm−1 that are respectively the characteristic peaks of C–O anti-symmetric stretching, C–O stretching, CC stretching and CO stretching in cellulose structure [40,41]. A small peak at ≈ 900 cm−1 that is due to C–O-C stretching at glucose linkage in polysaccharide structure was also observed [26]. In the case of as-syn 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW), FTIR peaks drastically reduced for the 3000−3600 cm−1 region and disappeared for the 900–1400 and 2900 cm−1 regions. This indicates that the structure of cellulose was destroyed after the heat treatment with microwave irradiation due to more accessibility of protons in CH2OH group that presents both inter- and intra- chain hydrogen bonds of cellulose structure [42]. Significantly, a peak at 760 cm−1 was clearly observed in as-syn 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) because of the appearance of the inorganic Ti-O stretching [43]. It could be clearly seen that Ti-O stretching peak was retained as an absorption peak in TiO2 (4-MW) and 5 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) while there was less absorption in other calcined C-doped TiO2. This result could be explained on the basis that there is a carbon layer covering the TiO2 surface. No significant OH stretching peak was observed in all calcined C-doped TiO2 photocatalysts due to the complete destruction of the molecular structure of cellulose by calcination. However, small absorption peaks were also observed at ≈ 1630 cm-1 in all photocatalyst samples which was attributed to the OH group of water absorption on the surface of the photocatalyst [26]. 3.1.4 Surface areas, pore volumes, and pore size and elemental analysis The results of the specific surface area (S BET ), average pore volume (V m ), average pore size (r p ) and elemental composition of C-doped TiO2 photocatalysts are listed in Table 1. In the case of microwave treating time, it was found that 10 % Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) (70 m2/g) had surface area lower than the C-doped TiO2 without MW treatment (10 % Cel-TiO2 (0-MW)) (85 m2/g). However, an increase of microwave treating time beyond 4 min enhanced the surface area, pore volume, average pore size of 10 % Cel-TiO2 (20-MW) to reach 119 m2/g, 0.6 m3/g and 19.9 nm, respectively. This result can be attributed to the fact that a longer microwave treating time leads to the inhibition of further aggregation of TiO2 particles due to the nucleation of TiO2 under microwave electric field [31,44]. With regard to the elemental composition (Table 1), it can be seen that the microwave treating time did not affect the carbon and hydrogen contents in the C-doped TiO2. The content of carbon (4.7–4.9 %) in calcined TiO2 samples corresponded to the carbon content in 10 % cellulose (4.18 % C) loaded during TiO2 synthesis. In the case of cellulose loading, we decided to treat TiO2 samples with different cellulose loadings with the same microwave treating time of 4 min. It was observed that the surface area of TiO2 (4-MW) reduced from 172 cm2/g to 76 and 69 cm2/g when the cellulose loadings were changed to 5 % and 10 %, respectively. This may be due to the higher amount of carbon from cellulose deposited and blocking the pores of TiO2. These results correlate with the increase of carbon content in TiO2 samples (2.9–4.9%). Thus, it can be concluded that the formation of carbon also led to the reduction of pore volume and pore size. However, C-doped TiO2 with further loading of cellulose (20 % Cel-TiO2 (4-MW)) showed a high increase in surface area. It is believed that this higher surface area is probably obtained from the surface area of carbon accumulated on TiO2 surface. Regarding elemental composition, TiO2(4-MW) without cellulose loading during synthesis showed the smallest content of carbon (2.9 %). On the other hand, hydrogen (1.3 %) and oxygen (10.8 %) contents were the highest. In the case of carbon, this can be regarded as just the remaining carbon obtained from the residual organic precursors whereas for H, it can be regarded as the surface hydroxyl group of TiO2 [45]. The increase of cellulose loading from 0 to 20 % in C-doped TiO2 synthesis results in the increase of the carbon content in the samples from 2.9 to 6.2 %. In contrast, the contents of hydrogen and oxygen slightly decreased with increasing cellulose loading because of the strong interactions between hydroxyl groups of TiO2 sol and cellulose [46]. 3.1.5 Optical property of C-doped TiO2 XPS was conducted to investigate the chemical status of the surface of C-doped TiO2 photocatalysts. Fig. 5 (a) exhibits the survey spectra of TiO2 (4-MW), 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) and 10 %Cel-TiO2 (0-MW). The survey spectra showed the presence of Ti, O and C elements. Fig. 5(b) shows the high resolution XPS spectra of Ti2p of the 3 samples. The strong Ti2p peaks located at the binding energy of ≈ 460 eV and 466 eV correspond to tetravalent Ti4+ species in TiO2 lattice. However, they also reveal a positive shift (≈ 1.9 eV) compared with the normal peaks of Ti2p3/2 and Ti2p1/2 that are present at ≈ 459 eV and 464 eV, respectively [47]. This is attributed possibly to the repulsion of Ti atom toward adjacent oxygen atoms in the crystal structure by oxygen vacancies that have a high positive charge. This results in the shortening of the Ti-O bonds [48]. Notably, only 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) had a small peak at ≈ 462 eV that was assigned to Ti3+ in the lattice of TiO2 [49]. This indicates that the carbon obtained from cellulose and microwave treatment had a synergistic effect which led to the formation of both Ti4+ and Ti3+ in the lattice of TiO2. Considering the high resolution O1s spectra in Fig. 5(c), it can be observed that O1s spectra of cellulose loaded TiO2 had two peaks at ≈ 531 eV and 533 eV. The peak at ≈ 531 eV corresponds to the O lattice (Ti-O-Ti) and the peak at ≈ 533 eV is assigned to Ti-O-C or oxygen vacancies [21,48]. The oxygen vacancies are normally coupled with Ti3+ in TiO2 lattice. TiO2 (4-MW) displayed only the peak at ≈ 531 eV that corresponded to Ti-O-Ti. Fig. 5(d) shows the XPS spectra of C1s of samples at high resolution. The C1s spectrum of C-doped TiO2 with and without microwave treating ((10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) and 10 %Cel-TiO2 (0-MW)) can be fitted to the peak located at ≈ 286 eV which could be assigned to C–O or C–OH bond. This result indicates that carbon was incorporated into the lattice TiO2 atom [21,50]. In the case without cellulose loading TiO2 (4-MW), two additional peaks were observed in C1s spectrum at ≈ 288 and 292 eV that were assigned to CO or C–O-Ti and π → π* transition, respectively [51,52]. The presence of C–O or C–OH bond in TiO2 (4-MW) might be due to the residual carbonate species formation obtained from calcination under N2 atmosphere. UV-vis DR spectra of all synthesized TiO2 samples, measured by using an inert plastic powder, which is a specific standard material of UV–vis spectrophotometer instrument as reference material, was performed by Industrial Service Section of National Nanotechnology Center of National Science and Technology Development Agency, Thailand. The spectra results are shown in Fig. 6 (a). The non-cellulose loaded 0 %Cel-TiO2(4-MW) photocatalyst (blue line) illustrates relatively higher photo-absorption activity in the UV region as compared with other cellulose loaded TiO2 photocatalysts. However, its photo-absorption clearly shows a decrease in the longer wavelength of the visible region (>400 nm). As the cellulose loading in TiO2 during synthesis was increased, the photo-absorption in the visible region also increased. Regarding microwave treating time, all C-doped TiO2 synthesized with longer microwave treating time had slightly lower photo-adsorption edges. The band gap of all synthesized TiO2 were estimated from the extrapolation of the linear fit for the plot of (αhν)1/2 onto the hv axis (Fig. 6(b)). The band gaps of the samples are shown in Table 1. It was found that the widest band gap (≈ 1.6 ev) was obtained from TiO2(4-MW). The increase of cellulose loading to 5 % led to a reduction of the band gap (≈ 0.5 ev of 5 %Cel-TiO2(4-MW). This is because the carbon tended to generate local energy between the conduction band and the valence band of TiO2 [46,53]. However, the increased absorbance in the case where there was excess cellulose loading was due to carbonaceous species on TiO2 which may not necessarily require a reduction of the energy gap of TiO2. In this case, an estimation of the band gap could not be made. The rough surface cluster of TiO2 with only small anatase crystal was formed by the rapid crystallization under an electric field of microwave irradiation. The longer microwave treating time reduced the size of anatase compared with non- microwave treated C-doped TiO2. Additionally, the presence of carbon in the lattice of TiO2 synthesized with microwave treatment facilitated the enhancement of photo-absorption in the visible region due to the formation of Ti3+ in the lattice of C-doped TiO2. This state of Ti3+ generated intermediate energy levels which induced decreased bandgaps and improved the visible light absorption of TiO2 photocatalyst. 3.2 Photocatalytic conversion of glycerol 3.2.1 Effect of microwave treating time Blank tests were conducted in which the photocatalytic conversions of glycerol without H2O2 as well as under a dark condition with TiO2. The results showed that glycerol conversions were very low. The conversions of glycerol without H2O2 and in the dark condition at the 8 h run time were 0.6 % and 2.8 %, respectively, hence they were not shown. Fig. 7 shows the photocatalytic conversions of glycerol obtained from 10 %Cel-TiO2 synthesized by non-microwave treatment or sol-gel method (0-MW) and microwave treatment method (4-MW and 20-MW). The photocatalytic conversion of glycerol with 10 % Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) provided the lowest conversion of glycerol (0.18 %) at 1 h of reaction time. If the reaction time is limited to just 1 h, 10 % Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) provided lower photocatalytic conversion of glycerol as compared with 10 % Cel-TiO2 (0-MW) and 10 % Cel-TiO2 (20-MW). In this case the photocatalytic conversion of glycerol was correlated to the surface area of the photocatalyst. The photocatalyst activity trend was: 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) <10 % Cel-TiO2 (20-MW) <10 % Cel-TiO2 (0-MW). This could be explained by the increase in the adsorption rate of glycerol on just the larger surface area of the photocatalyst for reactions within 1 h. After this time, the photocatalytic conversions all increased with increasing reaction time but at different rates. The glycerol photocatalytic conversion rate of 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) was the highest towards the highest equilibrium conversion at 8 h as compared with 10 %Cel-TiO2 (20-MW) and 10 %Cel-TiO2 (0-MW). This may mean that the visible light absorption activity takes at least 1 h in order to be activated in the photocatalyst. As observed, by applying microwave irradiation during synthesis, the photocatalytic activity of C-doped TiO2 increased because microwave treated C-doped TiO2 provided smaller anatase crystallite size than 10 %Cel-TiO2 (0-MW). However, 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) gave a photocatalytic activity (67.5 % in 8 h), which was higher than 10 %Cel-TiO2 (20-MW). In this case, this result corresponded to the higher visible light absorption of 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) as compared with the other conditions. The photocatalytic conversion of glycerol to value-added chemicals was achieved via photocatalysis under visible irradiation. Glyceraldehyde (GAL), dihydroxyacetone (DHA), formic acid (FA) and acetic acid (AA) were observed in the product solution of the photocatalytic oxidation of glycerol assisted with H2O2. These products can be used as platform molecules to synthesize other specific industrial chemicals [54,55]. The effect of microwave treating time on the yields of various products obtained from photocatalytic conversion of glycerol are shown in Fig. 8 . The microwave treated 10 % C-doped TiO2 photocatalysts provided higher yields of all products as compared with 10 %Cel-TiO2 (0-MW). This also corresponds to higher conversion of glycerol. The highest yields of all products were obtained from 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW). The yields of DHA, FA and AA were enhanced with increasing irradiation time. In contrast, the maximum yield of GAL reached 10 % in 2 h with 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW), then it slightly decreased with a longer irradiation time. 3.2.2 Effect of cellulose loading The photocatalytic conversions of glycerol with C-doped TiO2 photocatalysts synthesized by sol-microwave method with different cellulose loadings are shown in Fig. 9 . The result show that TiO2 (4-MW) synthesized without cellulose loading could be active under visible light because of the presence of small amount of carbon, as was mentioned previously. It is observed that the increase in cellulose loading in TiO2 tended to enhance the photocatalytic conversion of glycerol. This is because by increasing the cellulose loading during synthesis, the amount of carbon incorporated in the TiO2 lattice is increased. This increase in carbon content from 2.9 % to 4.9 % enhances the light harvesting and electron transfer ability of C-doped TiO2. A systematic mechanism of C-doped TiO2 for the photocatalytic conversion of glycerol under visible light is shown in Fig. 10 . The carbon incorporated in TiO2 acts as an acceptor of photo-excited electron from TiO2 which promotes charge transfer and restrains the potential trap that could allow electron-hole pair recombination. In addition, the carbon atom in TiO2 lattice and Ti3+ acts as a shallow trap in the sample which action results in the narrower band gap exhibited by C-doped TiO2 by the formation of intermediate energy levels between the valence band and the conduction band. This phenomenon broadens the light absorption region [56]. Nevertheless, it was observed that the glycerol conversion of 20 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW) (37.1 %) was lower than that of other photocatalysts. This could be explained on the basis that the excess loading of cellulose in C-doped TiO2 generated residual carbon on the TiO2 surface which hindered the adsorption of glycerol on the surface of TiO2. This result indicates that increasing the carbon content of C-doped TiO2 did not directly correlate with the glycerol conversion due to the effect of decreasing active surface area because of increased carbon coverage. The plots of product yields obtained from glycerol conversions with C-doped TiO2 synthesized with various cellulose loadings are illustrated in Fig. 11 . It was observed that the yields of products were in line with glycerol conversion. The yields of DHA, FA and AA tended to be enhanced with increasing irradiation time. The highest yields of each product from glycerol conversion under this study were obtained with 10 %Cel-TiO2 (4-MW). A pathway model of glycerol conversion to GAL, DHA, FA and AA is shown in Fig. 12 . This pathway shows that the photocatalytic conversion of glycerol can be possibly explained via photocatalytic oxidation reaction of reactive oxygen species. GAL and DHA are formed by oxidation of hydroxyl radicals (•OH) that are generated by 2 main routes. In the first route of •OH radical formation, the molecules of H2O initially attack at the lattice O sites (Ti-O•) on TiO2 surface and then are oxidized by photogenerated holes obtained from photon activation of TiO2 [57]. In the second route, •OH radicals are produced by the photolysis of H2O2 that is obtained from reduction of oxygen by photogenerated electrons [58]. In this study, a small volume of H2O2 was also added in the solution to assist in the rate of photocatalytic oxidation. GAL could then be continuously converted to FA and AA via photocatalytic oxidation of intermediate molecules such as acetaldehyde, glyceric acid, glycolic acid, glyoxylic acid and oxalic acid [59,60]. 3.2.3 Correlations between glycerol conversion and photocatalyst characteristics An attempt was made in this work to correlate the characteristics of the photocatalyst (anatase crystal size, surface area, pore volume, pore radius, carbon content and energy gap) with glycerol conversion so as to determine which properties mostly impacted glycerol conversion. Correlations between glycerol conversion and the characteristics of 10 % Cel-TiO2 synthesized with different sol-microwave treating times and C-doped TiO2 synthesized with different cellulose loadings under same sol-microwave treating of 4 min. are shown in Figs. 13 and 14, respectively. In the case of the effect of sol-microwave treating time, Fig. 13 shows good correlation between glycerol conversion and only the carbon content. The correlations of glycerol conversion with other characteristics (anatase crystallite size, surface area, pore radius, and band gap) were poor (hence, they are not shown). The relation between glycerol conversion and carbon content is displayed as in Eq. (5): (5) G l y c e r o l c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = 837.66 C 2 - 7909.4 C + 1.8711 In the case of the effect of cellulose loading, only the plot of glycerol conversion versus pore volume and carbon content were meaningful as displayed in Fig. 14(a) and (b), respectively. The results show that the relationships of glycerol conversion with pore volume and carbon content could be fitted with Eq. (6). (6) G l y c e r o l c o n v e r s i o n = - 3.80 C 2 + 40.14 C - 39.71 V - 33.99 where C is carbon content (%) and V is pore volume (m3/g). The obtained coefficients of carbon content and pore volume could be used to determine their impact on glycerol conversion. 4 Conclusions Photocatalytic reaction was successfully employed to convert glycerol, a by-product from biodiesel production process, into value-added chemicals. It is a simple, energy saving and environmentally friendly technology. In this work, value-added chemicals (glyceraldehyde, dihydroxyacetone, formic acid and acetic acid) were generated via photocatalytic oxidation of glycerol with C-doped TiO2 under visible light. The development of C-doped TiO2 synthesis was achieved via a cellulose loaded sol-microwave method. The synthesized C-doped TiO2 photocatalysts have different characteristic properties for different microwave treating times and cellulose loadings. The C-doped TiO2 synthesized by microwave irradiation provided smaller and lower dense clusters of irregular shape as compared with C-doped TiO2 synthesized by non-microwave treatment. The increase of microwave treating time tends to increase the surface area of C-doped TiO2 while the increase of cellulose loading increases the content of carbon which has an important influence in promoting high conversion of glycerol under visible light due to the reduction of the band gap of the photocatalyst. The carbon present in the lattice of the C-doped TiO2 facilitated light adsorption and electron transfer. However, excess carbon led to a decrease in the conversion of glycerol by reducing the adsorption surface area of the photocatalyst. Author contribution section C-doped TiO2 photocatalyst synthesized by cellulose loading and sol-microwave treatment was, for the first time, applied in the photocatalytic oxidation of glycerol under visible light to produce value-added chemicals. The C-doped TiO2 was synthesized using a one-step sol-microwave method with microcrystalline cellulose as the carbon source to achieve TiO2 of desirable visible light absorption, cluster size, surface area and band gap. An increase in microwave irradiation time from 0 to 20 min reduced the anatase crystal size from 6.5 to 5.9 nm and increased surface area, pore volume and pore radius from 85 to 119 m2/g, 0.1 to 0.6 m3/g and 3.0–19.9 nm, respectively. Carbon in the TiO2 lattice with microwave treatment affected the performance of C-doped TiO2 under visible light due to the formation of Ti3+ and oxygen vacancies in TiO2 structure. For example, a cellulose loading at 10 % (i.e. 10 %Cel-TiO2(4-MW)) provided the highest photo-conversion of glycerol (67.5 %) and highest yields of glyceraldehyde (10.0 %), dihydroxyacetone (7.4 %), formic acid (49.0 %) and acetic acid (1.8 %). On the other hand, excess residual carbon on TiO2 surface (e.g. 20 %Cel-TiO2(0-MW)) retarded the activity of the photocatalyst. coredata.dc:description: C-doped TiO2 photocatalyst synthesized using a one-step sol-microwave method with microcrystalline cellulose as the carbon source to achieve TiO2 of desirable visible light absorption, cluster size, surface area and band gap was applied in the photocatalytic oxidation of glycerol under visible light to produce value-added chemicals, for the first time. An increase in microwave irradiation time from 0 to 20 min reduced the anatase crystal size but increased the surface area, pore volume and pore radius. Carbon coupled with microwave treatment produced Ti3+ and oxygen vacancies in the TiO2 lattice of the C-doped TiO2 which yielded improved performance of the photocatalysts. For example, a cellulose loading at 10 % (i.e. 10 % Cel-TiO2(4-MW)) provided the highest photo-conversion of glycerol (67.5 %) and highest yields of glyceraldehyde (10.0 %), dihydroxyacetone (7.4 %), formic acid (49.0 %) and acetic acid (1.8 %). On the other hand, excess residual carbon on TiO2 surface (e.g. 20 % Cel-TiO2(0-MW)) retarded the activity of the photocatalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of C-doped TiO2 by sol-microwave method for photocatalytic conversion of glycerol to value-added chemicals under visible light
